com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.argument
Class ObjectArgs

java.lang.Object
  com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.argument.ObjectArgs

@FullyTested
public final class ObjectArgs
extends Object

This is a collection of static methods to check arguments received by methods. They range from the very simple but venerable checkNotNull(Object, String) to much more complex. The goal is to provide a wide range of checks that produce readable, detailed errors.

A few examples:

  • CollectionArgs.checkIndexAndCount(java.util.Collection, int, int, String, String, String)
  • ArrayArgs.checkNotEmptyAndElementsNotNull(Object[], String)
  • MapArgs.checkKeysAndValuesNotNull(java.util.Map, String)

Like Preconditions, most methods return the validated input. Javadocs carefully document all exceptions, both checked and unchecked, that may be thrown under various scenarios.

With the exception of PathArgs (and possibly a few others), all methods throw unchecked exceptions -- RuntimeException and its subclasses. Most frequently, IllegalArgumentException is thrown. 

     public void myMethod(List<String> strList) {
         this._strList = ObjectsArgs.checkNotNull(strList, "strList");
         // Do work here.
     }
Argument Names (argName, indexArgName, countArgName, etc.)

Argument names should not be null, empty (""), or only whitespace (" "). This would undermine efforts to report useful exception messages. If (and only if) a check fails and the argument name is considered invalid, additional text is appended to the exception message in the form of a warning. Example: "WARNING: Argument name 'indexArgName' is null"

This will alert developers about deficiencies in arguments passed to the check method without changing the behavior of the validation rules.

Finally, a note about my motivation to create this package of classes: I have written similiar argument checking routines libraries in C, C++, Perl, Python, JavaScript, VBA, C#, and Java over the years. It's time to put these ideas into open source.

Author:
Kevin Connor ARPE (kevinarpe@gmail.com)

Method Detail

checkNotNull

@FullyTested
public static <T> T checkNotNull(T ref,
                                             String argName)
Tests if an object reference passed as an argument is not null.

Parameters:
ref - an object reference
argName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList" or "searchRegex"
Returns:
the validated object reference
Throws:
NullPointerException - if ref is null

checkInstanceOfType

@FullyTested
public static <T> T checkInstanceOfType(T ref,
                                                    Class<?> destClass,
                                                    String refArgName)
This is a convenience method for checkInstanceOfType(Object, Class, String, String) where destClassArgName = "destClass".

checkInstanceOfType

@FullyTested
public static <T> T checkInstanceOfType(T ref,
                                                    Class<?> destClass,
                                                    String refArgName,
                                                    String destClassArgName)
Tests if a reference can be safely cast to another type. If you only have Class reference and not an object reference, see checkAssignableToType(Class, Class, String, String).

Type cast rules are defined by Class.isInstance(Object).

Examples of valid type casts: 

 String str = "abc";
 CharSequence seq = str;  // OK 
 CharSequence seq2 = (CharSequence) str;  // OK 
 CharSequence seq3 = (CharSequence) ((Object) str);  // OK
Examples of invalid type casts: 
 String str = "abc";
 Long num = str;  // compile-time type check error
 Long num = (Long) str;  // compile-time type check error
 Long num = (Long) ((Object) str);  // throws ClassCastException at run-time

Parameters:
ref - an object reference
destClass - destination type after cast
refArgName - argument name for ref, e.g., "strList" or "searchRegex"
destClassArgName - argument name for destClass, e.g., "strListClass" or "searchRegexClass"
Returns:
the validated object reference
Throws:
NullPointerException - if ref or destClass is null
ClassCastException - if ref cannot be safely cast to type destClass
See Also:
checkInstanceOfType(Object, Class, String), checkAssignableToType(Class, Class, String, String)

checkAssignableToType

@FullyTested
public static <TSrc,TDest> void checkAssignableToType(Class<TSrc> srcClass,
                                                                  Class<TDest> destClass,
                                                                  String srcClassArgName)
This is a convenience method for checkAssignableToType(Class, Class, String, String) where destClassArgName = "destClass".

checkAssignableToType

@FullyTested
public static <TSrc,TDest> void checkAssignableToType(Class<TSrc> srcClass,
                                                                  Class<TDest> destClass,
                                                                  String srcClassArgName,
                                                                  String destClassArgName)
Tests if a type can be safely cast to another type. If you have an object reference, see checkInstanceOfType(Object, Class, String, String).

Type cast rules are defined by Class.isAssignableFrom(Class).

For examples of valid and invalid type casts, see checkInstanceOfType(Object, Class, String, String).

Parameters:
srcClass - source type before cast
destClass - destination type after cast
srcClassArgName - argument name for srcClass, e.g., "strListClass" or "searchRegexClass"
destClassArgName - argument name for destClass, e.g., "strListClass" or "searchRegexClass"
Throws:
NullPointerException - if srcClass or destClass is null
ClassCastException - if type srcClass cannot be safely cast to type destClass
See Also:
checkAssignableToType(Class, Class, String), checkInstanceOfType(Object, Class, String, String)
